comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
EXEMPTIONS. 81 


SECTION XIV. 

EXEMPTIONS FROM THE PROVISIONS AS TO CLOSING HOURS. 

Exemptions as to Premises (1) Exemption Orders. The local 
authority of any licensing district may, upon the production 
of evidence that, for the accommodation of any considerable 
number of persons attending any public market or following 
any lawful trade or calling, it is desirable so to do, grant to 
any licensed victualler or licensed keeper of a refreshment 
house, or any person licensed to sell beer or cider by retail 
to be consumed upon the premises, an order exempting 
such person (on the days and during the times specified in 
such order) from the provisions of the Licensing Acts with 
respect to the closing of his premises except between the 
hours of one and two in the morning.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: For example, bars down at the docks were often exempted to cater for dockers and sailors odd hours.

comment.author: 7945368@N05
comment._content: The Anchor Hotel was "The Anchor Bar" when I was a young lad, then "The Hair of the Dog" when I was old enough to be drinking. It burnt down in between times, if I remember correctly. It's someone's house now. It was used in the filming of "Grabbers" - www.imdb.com/title/tt1525366/?ref_=nv_sr_1 Montgomery Terrace, which ends in St. Eugene's Hall, looks now just like it does in the picture. Local landmark "The White Wall" can be seen just be seen below the spire of St. Columb's. The whole green was walled in at one time, but only the White Wall is left. I think the wall was taken down around the time the Montgomerys - ancestors of Viscount Montgomery - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_Montgomery,_1st_Viscount_Mo... - donated it to the town. There is a plaque at the entrance to the green with the date on it, which might help dating the picture. Of course my local history might be off altogether. Also to help date the photo, I can't see the Masonic Hall which I think you should be able to see to the right of St. Eugene's Hall from this angle. That was built in 1903. Actually, looking at it on Street View , I don't think I can see it either. Thanks for the home town photo, Carol!

comment._content: A famous (locally) post card showing the same spot - www.movilleinishowen.com/gallery/postcards_old_and_new/po... The young lad is Aonghus Mc Nally, son of the actor Ray McNally, who were up on their holidays at the time.
